creator: craiga@mindwrap.com
text:
The html generated by the jsp:plugin tag could use some improvement.  The 
currently generated code, while matchin what Sun suggests for it's plugin, 
contains improperly nested tags and does not work for all browsers (Linux 
Mozilla 0.9.2 for example).

According to the JSP specification the jsp:plugin tag should generate 
"appropriate client browser dependent constructs".  Is there a reason why the 
generator code could not detect the client browser and just generate the 
OBJECT, EMBED or perhaps APPLET tags that are best for that browser?

BTW, I tried nesting APPLET tags inside the  jsp:fallback  and while that lets the 
applets run in Mozilla it causes them to be dispalyed twice in Netscape 4.77 (a 
Netscape bug no doubt).

creator: cmanolache@yahoo.com
text:
I don't know too much about the plugin, could you send some html ( what is
generated and what it should ? )

creator: craiga@mindwrap.com
text:
The "Test JSP" attachment shows a simpe case of the "jsp:plugin" tag.  You can 
see the code it generates in "Genrated HTML".  Note that in the generated code 
the <COMMENT>, <embed> and <noembed> tags are not well nested.  The 
intent of this, as I understand, it that Internet Explorer recognizes the "object" 
tag and uses it to define the plugin, and it recognizes the "COMMNET" tag 
which hides the "embed" and "noembed".   On the other had Netscape does not 
recognize "object" or "comment" so it can see the "embed" which it uses to 
define the plugin.  This code is somwhat "magical" and works fine for Netscape 
and IE.  The problem is that it IS somewhat magical and thus it can break other 
browsers..    The JSP spec says that "jsp:plugin" should "...generate HTML that 
contains the approptiate client browser dependent constructs..." -- It should be 
smart enough to recongize the client and generate code for that browser ( see 
Desired Output).

I understand the problem, but it seems I'm not smart enough to implement it :-)
IMHO it would be much better to implement such a smart behavior in a separate
tag, that can be used instead of jsp:plugin. If you can do such a tag, and it
works, we can try later to fix jsp:plugin based on this experience.
creator: cmanolache@yahoo.com
jreynolds@lane15.com
text:
I agree with Costin whole-heartedly.  In fact, based on what I've learned, I do 
not think the the jsp:plugin tag should be part of the base jsp tags at all.  
If you go out to Sun's page that discusses their HTML converter, 
http://java.sun.com/products/plugin/1.3/docs/tags.html 
you will see that the line:
"Webmasters may find one template better than others for their needs, and are 
encouraged to modify these templates themselves if necessary."

If Sun can't come up with a single template, the jsp:plugin tag has no chance 
of functioning properly.
